text:
Hi, I'm Jake Burns, Enterprise
Strategist with AWS.

Digital transformation
is integrating digital technology

in all areas, which can fundamentally
change how businesses

deliver value to customers,
while generating new revenue
streams.

Companies also adopt digital
technologies to make cultural

and operational shifts, in response
to emerging customer demands

and increased competition
in a constantly changing
economic environment.

COVID-19 changed our priorities,
our habits, and our needs.

As a result, customers
are raising their expectations

of the technology they use in
their daily lives.

According to Deloitte, 85 percent
of CEOs responded to the

pandemic by accelerating their 
digital transformation strategies.

Based on our experience,
the specific business goals

of digital transformation
are to improve the customer

journey, to benefit from digitally
optimizing operations,

and to exploit new business
models.

The transformation
of the customer journey starts

with a deep understanding
of the customer’s needs.

New, multi-experience
solutions, such as touch,

voice, and gestures, can meet
customers where they are by providing

digital solutions that integrate
into their daily lives.

For example, McDonald’s
transformed their customer

drive-through experience by 
using recommendations
based on location,

time of day, and the content
of past orders.

Digitally optimized operations
can lead to improved productivity

and reduced risk, which are critical
success factors in achieving
desired business outcomes.

Digital transformation
can optimize operations

in two ways: first, through
the capture, analysis,

and subsequent insights
gained from the growing data

within your organization;
and second, by using technology

to automate and integrate
existing processes.

For example, Belgian textile
manufacturer Bru Textiles

responded to customer demand
for faster delivery of custom
textiles.

They reduced time to market
by establishing a digital

division to use digital twins,
augmented reality, and virtual

reality within its design
and manufacturing processes.

Developing a new digital
business model empowers

your organization to rapidly
move into new markets, expand

your brand as an innovator,
and uncover and form new partnerships.

The growth in the use of mobile
devices and the availability

of compute platforms through
cloud computing is creating
new business models.

As an example, the state of Rhode
Island’s Department of Labor

and Training built an online
information dashboard with intelligent
chatbots.

This dashboard improved
transparency and provided

broader unemployment
support, rather than requiring

residents to go to multiple
applications and websites.
